questions.question_body: Which emperor was not deified after his death?
Marcus Aurelius wrote a work of philosophy entitled what?
What reforms were made law under the Lex Iulia issued by Augustus?
What is the sequence of emperors in "the year of the four emperors" in 69 CE?
Who was the British leader who lead the nearly successful revolt in 60/61 CE?
Which Roman general lost three legions at the Battle of Teutoburg Forrest?
Who claimed to have found "Rome a city of bricks, and left it a city of marble?"
Which emperor was responsible for the second incarnation of the Pantheon?
Who was the first emperor from North Africa?
What is the sequence of emperors in "the year of the five emperors" in 193 CE?

question_options.A: Pertinax, Septimius Severus, Didius Julianus, Alexander Severus, Caracalla
question_options.B: Pertinax, Didius Julianus, Pescinnius Niger, Clodius Albinus, Septimius Severus
question_options.C: Didius Julianus, Pescinnius Niger, Clodius Albinus, Pertinax, Septimius Severus
question_options.D: Septimius Severus, Carcalla, Macrinus, Elagalbus, Alexander Serverus

questions.question_body: In what year was the capital of the empire transferred from Rome to Milan?
Which Praetorian Prefect of Constantius Chlorus defeated the usurper Allectus in Britain?
Which youth was deified by Hadrian after he drowned in the Nile?
Which emperor rejected Christianity after Constantine made it the state religion?
Which dynasty is the latest?
Alaric sacked Rome in what year?
What was the name of the Judaean princess loved by the future emperor Titus?
What emperor required himself to be addressed as Dominus et Deus?
Who built a second wall, beyond Hadrian's Wall, in Scotland?
Livia, Antonia Major, and Agrippina Minor were important women during which dynasty?
Who was the daughter by Antony and Cleopatra?
The fortress of Masada was captured by which Roman general in 73?
How did Commodus die?
As the Roman Empire was meeting its end in the west in 476, who was ruling in the East?
What commander of the legions of the Upper Rhine conspired to replace Caligula with a senator named M. Aemilius Lepidus in 39?
Who was Galba's freedman advisor who brought word that the Senate had appointed him emperor?
Which member of the imperial family informed Tiberius of Sejanus' plot to seize power?
Which law granted Roman citizenship to all those living in free provinces?
Which emperor won the throne in an auction?
Which Palmyran queen conquered Egypt and expelled its Roman prefect?
Which emperor instituted the tetrarchy?
Who proposed to the Senate that C. Iulius Caesar Octavianus be given the name Augustus in 27 BC?
Which general of Vespasian defeated Vitellius' forces at Cremona in 69?
On what island did Tiberius spend the last years of his life?
Who was the Roman general who suppressed the revolt of Bar Cochba under Hadrian?
Whom did Diocletian defeat at the River Margus in 285 to become sole emperor?
Which Roman woman conspired to kill her grandson and daughter in the 3rd century CE?
Which woman of the 5th century was both the captive and later the wife of the Visigoth king Ataulf?
Which general under Domitian defeated the Dacians at Tapae in 88?
Which emperor was told by Apollodorus of Rhodes to "go and play with his pumpkins!"?
Which famous letter-writer wrote letters about the eruption of Vesuvius?
Where did Contantius Chlorus die?
Which tetrarch was born circa 260 and died of an illness at Sardica in May of 311?
In 456, what Suevian commander rebelled in Ravenna and declared himself emperor?
When did Judea become and province?
Which emperor planned an invasion of Britain, but did not carry it out?
Which sister did Caligula have made into a goddess?
Who was the Roman general who waged an inconclusive guerrilla style offensive against the Numidian prince Tacfarinas in 22?
Which general conquered Mauretania under Claudius?
In what year was the emperor Valens killed?
What Danubian successor to Gallienus continued the military success of his predecessor by crushing the Alamanni at Lake Benacus and leading the Romans to a series of victories against the Goths?
What emperor faced a coup from the praetorian prefect Nymphidius Sabinus in the earliest days of his short reign?
What first wife of Augustus did he divorce having never consummated the marriage – even going so far as to send a not to her mother saying that she was still in "mint" condition?
Which of the emperors of the "Year of the Four Emperors" rules for the shortest time?
What name was shared by no less than four powerful women of the Severan dynasty?
What general was the de facto ruler of Rome for approximately the first ten months of Vespasian's rule, as Vespasian was still in the East?
What is the total of the number of Julio-Claudian, Flavian, and "Good" emperors?
What name was given to the split governmental system engineered by Diocletian?
Whose mother was named Helena and was made a saint by the Church?
What Roman general and governor of Judaea was murdered in 118, possibly on the orders of the emperor Hadrian, who feared his popularity and good standing with the army?
Which of these was NOT a title won by the emperor Trajan as a result of his victories?
When the troops proclaimed Constantine I emperor after his father Constantius Chlorus' death, what Caesar under his father was the rightful choice to succeed to the title of Augustus?
What did the Constitutio Antoniniana of Commodus in 212 do?

question_options.A: It allowed for the distribution of grain to the poor.
question_options.B: It made the Danube River the permanent eastern boundary of the Empire.
question_options.C: It claimed that Rome had rights to whatever lands they wished to have.
question_options.D: It extended citizenship to all free inhabitants of the Empire.

questions.question_body: Successes against which Armenian king earned the Roman general Corbulo the envy and mistrust of Nero, eventually causing Nero to force him to commit suicide?
What demand did the Praetorians make of the new emperor Nerva – a demand which he acceded to?

question_options.A: They wanted to execute Domitian's killers
question_options.B: They wanted to double their own pay
question_options.D: They wanted immunity from Roman law

questions.question_body: Which of the claimaints to the imperial throne in 193 was proclaimed emperor by his troops in Britain and Gaul after the murder of Pertinax?
In what year was the famed Battle of the Milvian Bridge?
Which Praetorian, the murderer of Caligula, was one of the few to ever be punished for his crime, as he was killed with the same sword with which he stabbed Caligula?
By whom were Balbinus and the famous Pupienus hailed as emperor in 238 after Maximinus' death?
What Roman-friendly king of Armenia did the Persian Narses drive out in 296, beginning a series of battles with Galerius and Diocletian?
Which woman married an equestrian, Rufrius Crispinus, and the future emperor Otho, before marrying the current emperor Nero in 62 AD?
At the famed Conference of Milan of 313, a long-awaited marriage took place between Constantia and whom?
Which of these events in the reign of Constantine happened LAST?
What does the emperor Vitellius' name mean?
Which Roman emperor was the son of the ill=fated Valerian?
Who was the first man to hold the imperial throne without having been a senator?
Against what Persian "King of Kings" did Alexander Severus fight a war in Syria and Cappadocia until he handed on the title to his son Shapur I in 240?

Which enterprising general was sworn to Galba, turned traitor to support Vitellius, then turned on Vitellius and tried to get his troops to support Vespasian? He was eventually put to death for treachery (finally) by the emperor Titus?
Which of these correctly describes the familial relationship between the emperors Titus and Domitian?
What was the name of Titus' Jewish lover, whom he was forced to send away because of public opinion?
Augustus forced Tiberius to adopt Germanicus as his own son, this displacing which natural son of Tiberius'?
What eldest son of Constantine the Great was put to death by his father on charges that appear to have been false?
At what site in Gaul did Septimius Severus defeat and kill Clodius Albinus in 197?
It is thought that the survival of the empire during the reign of the young Gordian III is in large part due to the brilliance of his father-in-law, the praetorian prefect. What was his name?
What Dacian capital city did Trajan finally occupy after a long battle in 106?
Which emperor issued the well-intentioned but disastrous Edict on Maximum Prices?
What was the name of the young Bithynian Greek boy who was the lifelong companion of Hadrian?
Leading up to the Battle of Adrianople, the Goths had asked for and been granted permission to settle in Roman territory because of the raids and pressure of what other people?
Which emperor, who liked his attendants to call him Hercules, was strangled in his bath on the last day of 192?
In what year was the Roman disaster in the Teutoberg Forest?
What 16 year old found himself Augustus after his father Valentinian I died 375?
Where was Vitellius holding command of two legions when they declared him emperor in 69 AD?
Which of these women was NOT one of the four wives of the emperor Claudius?
What son of Macrinus served as his Caesar for just over a year before being killed along with his father?
With whose death in 476 do we traditionally mark the end of the Western Roman Empire?
When Claudius invaded Britain, he actually did so at the invitation of several British chieftains who feared what man's power?
Who was the leader of the famed Jewish revolt against Hadrian in 132?
To which province did the aged and sick Diocletian retire after his abdication?
What did Marcus Aurelius study under Cornelius Fronto?
What Illyrian commander, the military equal of the great Aurelian, was declared emperor by the army of the assassination of the transitory emperor Tacitus?
Which praetorian prefect of Nero worked with Seneca the Younger to ensure stability for the first years of the young emperor's reign?
Excluding Antoninus Pius, which of the five good emperors ruled for the longest amount of time?
What emperor was responsible for the Massacre at Alexandria?
Put the following emperors in order from shortest rule to longest rule.
What Praetorian Prefect and maternal cousin of Septimius Severus was given great power by the emperor but was later killed because Caracalla loathed his daughter?
Which Roman general lost three legions at the Battle of Teutoburg Forrest?
Who member of the Julio-­‐Claudian family died after falling off his horse in 9 B.C.?
Which praetorian prefect was responsible for elevating Gordion III?
Which of the following emperors was not born in Italy?
What emperor ruled for one year with his brother before being killed by him in front of their mother?
Which of these emperors succeeeded Titus?
Which Praetorian Prefect of Constantius Chlorus defeated the usurper Allectus in Britain?
What battle of 31 B.C. gave Octavian supremacy over the Roman world?
Which emperor defeated Maxentius at the Milvian Bridge in 312 and strongly promoted Christianity throughout the empire?
Which dynasty is the earliest?
Who sacked Rome in 410?
Whom was Tiberius forced to divorce in order to marry Julia the Elder?
Who was the mother of the emperor Nero?
Who was responsible for creating the poisons that led to the emperor Claudius' death?
Which emperor was known as the "Apostate" for his attempts to restore paganism?
What emperor died at the battle of Adrianople in 378 A.D.?
During what emperor's reign did Simon Bar-­‐Kochba lead a revolt in Palestine?
Who strangled Commodus?
Who ruled the Roman empire in the east from 457-­‐474?
What commander of the legions of the Upper Rhine conspired to replace Caligula with a senator named M. Aemilius Lepidus in 39 A.D.?
Who was NOT an emperor in 238 A.D.?
What praetorian prefect had a great deal of power during the time of Tiberius?
Which emperor granted a law which gave Roman citizenship to all freedmen in the Empire?
What emperor received the throne by purchasing it from the Praetorian Guard?
Which Palmyran youth was the son of the infamous Zenobia?
Which emperor was responsible for heavy prosecution of the Christians during his rule from 249-­‐251?
Which emperor was the last to rule in the West?

On what island did Tiberius spend a part of his life during the reign of Augustus before he became emperor?
What emperors reigned marked Rome's 900th anniversary?
Who ruled as joint Augustus with Diocletian beginning in 286 A.D.?
Which of the following women of the Severan Dynasty was the mother of Elagabalus?
Who was the wife of Trajan?

What Roman emperor was also a stoic philosopher?
Which tetrarch died in Eburacum in 306?

Which emperor's invasion of Britain resulted in a collection of seashells?
Claudius had his son Britannicus with which wife?
What Roman general was killed at the (First) Battle of Tapae in 88 A.D.?

Which barracks emperor routed a huge Gothic army at Naissus in 268 A.D.?
The tetrarchy began in _________________with the designation of Constantius Chlorus and Galerius as "Caesars."
The beginning of the Roman Empire is often dated from 27 BC. when

question_options.A: Marc Anthony was defeated at Actium.
question_options.C: Octavian returned power to the Senate and received it back.

questions.question_body: Who coordinated the ambush in 9 AD that resulted in Augustus losing legions?
You can visit a sumptuous mausoleum in Ravenna said to have been built for Galla Placidia, who was:
During whose reign did Pontius Pilate served as governor of Judea?
Who ordered the massacre in Thessalonica when the local inhabitants were protesting the presence of a Gothic garrison in their city?
Which of these so-called Barracks Emperors was NOT killed by his own soldiers?
The uprising in Palmyra led by Zenobia occurred during the reign of:
The Marcomannic Wars more or less defined the military record of Marcus Aurelius. Which of the following might be another name for this conflict?
Who was defeated and killed by the Visigoths in 378 AD at the Battle of Adrianople?
Which emperor committed suicide?
Whom did G. Calpurnius Crassus fail to remove from power in 97 AD?
During the reign of Domitian, Agricola let fierce fighting against what group?
This Jewish historian and scholar initially fought against the Romans but later became an advisor to Titus.
Who appointed P. Salvius Aper and Q. Ostorius Scapula as the first Praetorian prefects?
What duty did Augustus take up as a result of widespread famine in 22 B.C.?
Which city did Commodus rename as a colony after himself?
This term refers to the process used by the Flavian Emperors to choose someone for the Roman Senate.
Who was the longest reigning Roman emperor?
What was one of Hadrian's nicknames?
Which emperor came to power as a result of the mutiny at Moguntiacum which overthrew Severus Alexander?
The first to sack Rome since Brennus the Gaul was:
During what year of Nero's reign did a great fire destroy a large part of Rome?
In 27 B.C., Gaius Iulius Octavianus received what title of honor used by all Roman emperors except Vitellius?
What honorific title did Vitellius use as emperor?
The Basilica Ulpia was constructed by
Who was the rich senator who purchased his reign at auction in 193?
In 40, Caligula received an ovation in Rome on his birthday for his "campaign" at the English Channel from which he brought back what unusual plunder?
Domitian is notorious for all of the following reasons EXCEPT:

question_options.A: He brought back the horrors of delatio and maiestas.
question_options.C: He executed Vestal Virgins on charges of corruption.
question_options.D: He denied himself divine honors in the Eastern fashion.

questions.question_body: During the reign of Honorius, the capital was moved in fear of invasion to:
Those fears turned out to be valid when, in spite of the relocation, ________ was deposed in the new capital, thus bringing an end to the western empire.
Julia Mamaea, who bribed the Praetorian Guard in 222 AD to assassinate both her sister and her nephew, was the daughter of Julia ______.
The eruption of Mount Vesuvius destroyed the cities of Pompeii and Herculaneum during the reign of:
Poppaea Sabina, wife of Nero, had previously been married to which future emperor?
Who was the wife of Trajan, admired for her simplicity, dignity, fidelity, and virtue?
After a few years of ruling, Tiberius retired to Capri and appointed this Praetorian prefect to execute the duties of emperor.
The following were Praetorian prefects under Commodus EXCEPT
Who led a conspiracy against Nero in 65 A.D.?
What emperor first attempted to abolish Christianity throughout the Empire?
How was Ataulf, who led the Visigoths into Gaul in 412 A.D., related to his predecessor Alaric?
What office did Augustus assume in 12 B.C.?
Where did Licinius suffer his final defeat in 324 A.D.?
Stephanus, a palace domestic, has been named as the assassin of which emperor?
At the fall of the Western Roman Empire, we know that Odoacer/Odovacar deposed Romulus Augustulus, but who was the emperor in the east?
To what Syrian queen was Septimus Severus married?
What Illyrian emperor followed Tacitus and his brother Florianus?
As the first emperor who claimed divinity during his life, Caligula ordered a legate Petronius to set up his statue where?

question_options.A: in the temple of Jupiter Optimus Maximus
question_options.B: on the Acropolis near the Parthenon
question_options.D: in the center of the Forum Romanum

questions.question_body: What "ignoble son of a noble father" had himself depicted with Hercules' emblems of a club and lion's skin and appeared frequently in the arena as a hunter of wild beasts or gladiator?
Which Greek town in Egypt was founded by Hadrian?
Where did Augustus die?
What wife of an emperor was particularly active in promoting the cult of Cybele and was deified immediately after her death, ca. 140 A.D.?
From what did Gratian withdraw imperial support in 382 A.D.?

question_options.A: gladiatorial games involving prisoners of war
question_options.B: crucifixions as a standard death penalty

questions.question_body: What enemies of Rome did Vologases lead in 51 A.D.?
Who assisted Caracalla in the murder of his own brother Geta?
Who was the early martyr of the Christian Church who completely overturned the existing male-dominated social and political order at Carthage in 203 A.D.?
Which emperor is primarily responsible for building the Pantheon, even though he preserved the conventional façade and Agrippa's dedicatory inscription?
Who was the first wife of the emperor Claudius?
Who was one of the most important freedwomen in Roman history, who served both Claudius and Nero and became Vespasian's mistress until his marriage?
Diocletian's first edict against the Christians, issued in 303 A.D., called for what?

question_options.A: imprisonment of Christian clergy of all ranks
question_options.B: mandatory sacrifices to the state gods
question_options.C: destruction of Christian churches and books
question_options.D: immediate loss of privileges for Christians of higher classes

questions.question_body: Who was Constantine's mother whose conversion to Christianity has been distorted by the biases of Christian boosters and pagan distractors?
What German was the virtual ruler of the western Empire from 456 A.D. until his death in 472 A.D.?
Of whom was Boadicea/Boudicca the queen?
What future emperor once fled Rome in the disguise of a priest of Isis?
In 73 A.D., what sheer rock fortress was taken by the Romans after a six-month siege and the construction of a large earthern ramp?

Three catastrophes marred the brief reign of Titus: the violent eruption of Vesuvius and subsequent destruction of Herculaneum, Stabiae and Pompeii; a great fire in Rome which raged for three days; and…

question_options.B: a massive rebellion by the people of Judaea
question_options.C: a conspiracy plot by Saturninus, the governor of upper Germany
question_options.D: a significant military loss at the hands of a Sarmatian tribe

questions.question_body: What king's death is dramatically detailed on the column of Trajan?
What province did Pescennius Niger govern prior to his revolt against Didius Julianus and Septimius Severus?
Who was the first princeps to reach the throne without prior membership in the Senate?
At what battle did Constantine order the chi and rho to be placed upon the shields of his soldiers?
Where did Maximian establish his imperial residence?
In 429 A.D. whom did Gaiseric lead to begin seizing North Africa?
Against what bishop of Constantinople did the Augusta Eudoxia conspire?
Augustus personally led the fight against the Cantabrians and Asturians around BC in what location?
Who successfully urged Tiberius into semi-retirement in 26 A.D.?
Which emperor affronted the Senate by becoming the first to hold the office of censor and purging that body of some old members?
Where did Vespasian send Petilius Cerialis and Julius Frontinus to resume Rome's conquest?
Who was the first emperor of provincial origin?
Whom did Hadrian commission to draw up an edictum perpetuum binding all present and future praetors to a set code of laws and court procedures?
Which council did Constantine summon in Bithynia in 325 A.D.?
What emperor served as the last to rule over both the western and eastern halves of the empire?
Romulus Augustulus was appointed emperor by whom?
When did Augustus revive the Ludi Saeculares?
Who was Augustus' first choice as successor?
What Danubian officer killed Arrius Aper with his own hand and was then proclaimed emperor by his troops?
What was the name of the Armenian king who was killed by his own nephew Radamistus with some assistance from the Romans in 52?
Who taught rhetoric to Marcus Aurelius?
Under whose leadership was Mauretania divided into two imperial provinces?
Under which emperor were the empire's borders at their largest extent?
Who was the first emperor of the Julio-Claudian dynasty?
In what year did Octavian symbolically return power to the senate, and in return, was granted the name "Augustus"?
The Tetrarchy, a system of governance that resulted in the Roman Empire splitting into four distinctly governed parts was the brainchild of which emperor?
Which emperor issued an edict of toleration in 362 AD ordering the re-opening of traditional Roman "pagan" temples?
At The Battle of ______ Constantine I scored a decisive victory over his co-emperor, Maxentius.
Issued in 313 AD, the Edict of ______ officially authorized the Christian religion to be practiced without persecution throughout the empire.
In what year did the so-called "Year of the Four Emperors" take place?
Which of the following cities was destroyed alongside Pompeii by the eruption of Vesuvius in 79 AD?
What enemy commander was responsible for the disastrous Roman defeat at the Battle of Teutoburg Forest?
After Tiberius retreated from Rome to his island estate on Capri in 26 AD, which of his confidants assumed the administrative authority of the empire?
Which Julio-Claudian, who was also a historian, was known to have a limp and act as if he were stupid in order to protect himself from those who sought to harm him?
Julia Domna was the wife of which Severan emperor?
What were the soldier emperors who ruled for the fifty-or-so years following the end of the Severan Dynasty called?
Upon which of his family members did the emperor Caracalla pass a Damnatio Memoriae in 211 AD?
Who was the emperor who won the principate in an auction following the death of Pertinax?
The emperor Constantine I was married which sister of his mortal enemy, Maxentius?
Zenobia was queen of which break-away state from the Roman Empire around the year 268 AD?
What was the name of the horse that emperor Gaius was said by the biographer Suetonius to have appointed consul?
After which dynasty of emperors is the "Colosseum" named?
Which Illyrian emperor around 250 AD required citizens to offer all sacrifices in the presence of a magistrate and a witness?
Who becomes "King of Italy" after the fall of the Western Roman Empire in 476 AD?
What was the exquisite house created on public land following the Great Fire of Rome by Nero in 64 AD?
Which of the following was NOT an author implicated and eliminated after the Pisonian Conspiracy of 65 AD?
Which of his wars did Marcus Aurelius have represented on his namesake monumental column?
Which of the following prominent imperial women was the wife of Antoninus Pius?
What later Roman emperor was given the title "Restitutor Orbis" as a result of his victory over the pariah "Gallic Empire" which formed circa 260 AD?
Cleander and Perennis saw their fortunes rise and fall under the service of what emperor?
What was the name of Nero's second wife, whom he himself killed in a fit of rage along with her unborn baby?
The Roman general Aetius was credited for stopping which impending threat from attacking the Roman Empire in 451 AD?
Which emperor advocated the worship of the Holy Stone of Emesa (a meteorite fragment)?
Who was the Roman client-king who the emperor Domitian recognized as the legitimate rule of the Dacians in 89 AD?
Upon which member of the Roman Pantheon did emperor Gaius declare war on during his attempted expansion into Britain?
Who was the first emperor to have committed suicide?
Which Julio-Claudian was the uncle of the Roman hero and general, Germanicus?
Which of the following emperors fashioned himself "dominus et deus"?
Which emperor was infamously captured by the shahanshah of the Sassanid Empire, Shapur I?
Who assumed imperial power at the request of Constantius's sister after the death of Constans?
Which Roman emperor was responsible for elevating all free men under Roman dominion to the ranks of the Roman citizenry with his trademark law, the Constitutio Antoniniana?
Which Roman legal expert served in the inner circle of both Hadrian and Antoninus Pius?

Who was the Romano-Jewish scholar who, though initially joining the rebellion in Judea against the Romans, became a close advisor to the emperor Titus and an authoritative historian on the Jewish Wars?
Which praetorian prefect was Gordian III's father in law?
Constantine re-unified the empire by defeating Licinius in a series of clashes, the last of which was the Battle of ______.
Where did the usurper Domitius Alexander, proclaimed Augustus in 308 AD, rule?
What Armenian capital city was taken by Lucius Verus?
The Cult of ______, which the Romans considered derived from Zoroastrianism, was widely practiced by the soldiers of the Roman army from the 1st through the 4th centuries AD?
During the Year of the Four Emperors, which general was proclaimed emperor by the armies of the Lower Rhine?
Which emperor was killed by Ricimer in August, 461 AD?
According to the Historia Augusta, with what object did Elagabalus allegedly asphyxiate some of his dinner guests with?
After being appointed head of his father's Praetorian Guard, Titus was able to put down which conspirator and secure his position as emperor-to-be?
Which Roman emperor began construction on the Colosseum?
The Roman Empire reached its greatest territorial extent under which of the Five Good Emperors?
________ was the last Roman emperor to rule in the West.
Which Roman divided the empire under the Tetrarchy?
What emperor, also a Stoic philosopher, died of the plague at Vindobona?
The disaster at Teutoburg Forest occurred during the reign of _____.
What Germanic king deposed Romulus Augustulus?
Which emperor granted himself the title Dominus et Deus?
What Palmyran queen did Aurelian defeat, earning himself the title Restitutor Orientis?
Which emperor was known as "the Apostate" for his attempt to restore paganism?
Who celebrated the 800th anniversary of the founding of Rome?
Roman citizenship was extended to all free men in the empire by which decree?
What man constructed the Pantheon in addition to two aqueducts?
Which of the following was NOT a wife of Claudius?
St. Ambrose forced Theodosius I to repent for the massacre at which city?
What freedman of Commodus sold 25 consulships in one day?
Whom did Septimius Severus appoint as Caesar in order to focus his war effort against Pescennius Niger?
Which emperor built a wall from the River Tyne to the Solway Firth?
This emperor was captured by Shapur I and died in captivity.
In 107 AD, Trajan made _____ a Roman province.
Whose original name was Bassianus?
Which of the following was NOT an influential freedman of Claudius?
What emperor's tax on public toilets was so unpopular that they were nicknamed after him?
Whose death in 4 AD caused a crisis of succession?
Who was the wife of Antoninus Pius?
At what battle was Stilicho victorious over Alaric in 402 AD?
What tribal leader conducted the resistance to Claudius's invasion of Britain?
What year marked the first time Rome had co-emperors?
Which two 3rd-century AD emperors have been credited for a major victory over a Gothic coalition at the Battle of Naissus?
What emperor was reported to have been killed by lightning after sacking Ctesiphon?
Domitius Ulpianus was the praetorian prefect for which early 3rd-century AD emperor?
Who was the last emperor to be buried in the Mausoleum of Augustus?
Augustus did all the following to suppress rioting in Rome EXCEPT _____.

question_options.A: continuing an existing ban on unlicensed collegia
question_options.B: imposing harsher punishments for crimina publica
question_options.D: making the office of praefectus urbi permanent

questions.question_body: Who was appointed Caesar in the West under the Second Tetrarchy?
Whom did Didius Julianus outbid for the imperial throne?
Aemilius Aemilianus's victory at the Battle of Interamna in 253 AD led to the death of what emperor?
Anthemius and Pulcheria acted as regents for what 5th-century AD emperor?
What year marked the beginning of Tiberius's "retirement" to Rhodes?
In whose court did Constantine serve at the start of the Second Tetrarchy (late 305 – early 306 AD)?
What man was put to death for conspiring to install his grandson Cn. Pedianus Fuscus on the throne in 136 AD?
Who succeeded Sejanus as Praetorian Prefect?
What deity, originally the agent of Ahura-Mazda, served as the counterpart to Ahriman but later became the central deity of a Roman mystery cult?
What governor of Pannonia did Gallienus defeat when the former rose as a pretender to the throne?
Which statement about the Agrippina the Elder and Agrippina the Younger is WRONG?

question_options.A: Both had a husband who was probably poisoned.
question_options.B: Both were exiled to an island in the Tyrrhenian Sea.

questions.question_body: This lieutenant of Trajan crushed Jewish rebellions in Egypt and Cyrene, preventing further rebellion until that of Bar Kochba.
Which emperor reorganized an Egyptian fleet as the classis Augusta Alexandrina to ensure the safe and regular delivery of grain to Rome?
Augustus made an appointment to which religious office, which had been vacant since 87 BC?
What man helped L. Domitius Domitianus assume the title of emperor in Alexandria before being crushed by Diocletian?
This commander was responsible for the final abandonment of the Antonine Wall.
What man led the assassins that beat Agrippina the Younger to death after her failed assassination attempt on the Bay of Naples?
